title: Female Russian spy released from US prison and deported
text:
Convicted Russian agent Maria Butina was greeted with a hero’s welcome when she landed in Moscow (Picture: REUTERS)

A Russian pro-gun activist convicted of acting as an agent to influence US policy has been freed from prison.

Maria Butina, 31, admitted conspiring with a Russian official and two Americans to infiltrate the National Rifle Association – a group closely aligned with US conservatives and Republican politicians, including President Donald Trump.

She was jailed for 18 months for trying to create unofficial lines of communication to shape Washington’s policy toward Moscow.

She has been released early for good behaviour and was greeted with a hero’s welcome on her return to her native country today.

The Russian government has described the case against Butina as ‘fabricated’.

Maria Butina spent almost 18 months in a Florida prison (Picture: REUTERS)

She admitted being a secret agent for the Kremlin and trying to infiltrate conservative U.S. political groups while Donald Trump rose to power (Picture: Alexandria Detention Center)

After her release, she spoke of wanting to reunite with her family and thanked the people of her country for their support.

‘I want to be at home’, she told reporters on her flight from Miami to Moscow.

‘I need some time to adapt.

‘At the moment, I only want to reunite with my family and thank everyone who supported me.

‘I would not make it without my people, citizens of my country.’

Butina’s 18-month sentence included the nine months she spent incarcerated after her July 2018 arrest.

Journalists wait for Butina at Sheremetyevo International Airport, Moscow (Picture: Reuters)

She was welcomed by friends and family upon the arrival (Picture: Reuters)

The first thing she did was hug her father, Viktor Butin (Picture: Reuters)

She was kept at a low-security prison in Tallahassee and was scheduled for release in early November.

The first thing Butina did after she landed was hug her father Viktor Butin, 57, a businessman, who met her at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo airport.

Her US lawyers said on Friday that her release and deportation ‘closes the book on an inflated prosecution that never should have been brought’.

Butina’s case was separate from former Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 US election, which detailed numerous contacts between Trump’s campaign and Russia.

Federal prosecutors said Butina did not engage in ‘traditional’ spy craft, but worked behind the scenes to make inroads in conservative political circles and promote friendlier US-Russian relations.

That included arranging dinners in Washington and New York and attending events to meet prominent politicians.

The Russian Government say the case against Burtina was completely fabricated (Picture: TASS)

The men Butina was convicted of conspiring with were not charged (Picture: Reuters)

The Russian official with whom Butina was found guilty of conspiring with, a deputy governor of Russia’s central bank, was never charged in the case, but was hit with sanctions by the US Treasury.

Advertisement

One of the two Americans referenced in her case was conservative political activist Paul Erickson, her boyfriend.

Erickson also wasn’t charged for his links to Butina, but was indicted on unrelated wire fraud and money laundering charges in South Dakota, in a case that is still pending.

Last year, Russia’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs accused the United States of forcing Butina to make a false confession to ‘absolutely ridiculous charges’ of being a Russian agent.

President Vladmir Putin said in April: ‘It’s not clear what she was convicted of or what crime she committed.

‘I think it’s a prime example of “saving face”. They arrested her and put the girl in jail.

‘But there was nothing on her, so in order not to look totally stupid they gave her, fixed her up, with an 18-month sentence to show that she was guilty of something.’

The Russian Embassy in the United States tweeted on Friday that ‘more and more’ US politicians ‘understand the absurdity of the charges made against her’.

description: Female Russian spy Maria Butina released from US prison and deported
